Content: You are running a web application on Cloud Run for few hundred users. Some of your users complain that the initial web page of the application takes much longer to load than the following pages. You want to follow Google's recommendations to mitigate the issue. What should you do?
Option1: A. Set the minimum number of instances for your Cloud Run service to 3.
Option2: B. Set the concurrency number to 1 for your Cloud Run service.
Option3: C. Set the maximum number of instances for your Cloud Run service to 100.
Option4: D. Update your web application to use the protocol HTTP/2 instead of HTTP/1.1.

Content: You are building a data lake on Google Cloud for your Internet of Things (loT) application. The loT application has millions of sensors that are constantly streaming structured and unstructured data to your backend in the cloud. You want to build a highly available and resilient architecture based on Google-recommended practices. What should you do?
Option1: A. Stream data to Pub/Sub, and use Dataflow to send data to Cloud Storage.
Option2: B. Stream data to Pub/Sub, and use Storage Transfer Service to send data to BigQuery.
Option3: C. Stream data to Dataflow, and use Dataprep by Trifacta to send data to Bigtable.
Option4: D. Stream data to Dataflow, and use Storage Transfer Service to send data to BigQuery.

Content: You are running out of primary internal IP addresses in a subnet for a custom mode VPC. The subnet has the IP range 10.0.0.0/20, and the IP addresses are primarily used by virtual machines in the project. You need to provide more IP addresses for the virtual machines. What should you do?
Option1: A. Add a secondary IP range 10.1.0.0/20 to the subnet.
Option2: B. Change the subnet IP range from 10.0.0.0/20 to 10.0.0.0/18.
Option3: C. Change the subnet IP range from 10.0.0.0/20 to 10.0.0.0/22.
Option4: D. Convert the subnet IP range from IPv4 to IPv6.

Content: Your company requires all developers to have the same permissions, regardless of the Google Cloud project they are working on. Your company’s security policy also restricts developer permissions to Compute Engine, Cloud Functions, and Cloud SQL. You want to implement the security policy with minimal effort. What should you do?
Option1: A. • Create a custom role with Compute Engine, Cloud Functions, and Cloud SQL permissions in one project within the Google Cloud organization. • Copy the role across all projects created within the organization with the gcloud iam roles copy command. • Assign the role to developers in those projects.
Option2: B. • Add all developers to a Google group in Google Groups for Workspace. • Assign the predefined role of Compute Admin to the Google group at the Google Cloud organization level.
Option3: C. • Add all developers to a Google group in Cloud Identity. • Assign predefined roles for Compute Engine, Cloud Functions, and Cloud SQL permissions to the Google group for each project in the Google Cloud organization.
Option4: D. • Add all developers to a Google group in Cloud Identity. • Create a custom role with Compute Engine, Cloud Functions, and Cloud SQL permissions at the Google Cloud organization level. • Assign the custom role to the Google group.

Content: You are working for a hospital that stores its medical images in an on-premises data room. The hospital wants to use Cloud Storage for archival storage of these images. The hospital wants an automated process to upload any new medical images to Cloud Storage. You need to design and implement a solution. What should you do?
Option1: A. Create a Pub/Sub topic, and enable a Cloud Storage trigger for the Pub/Sub topic. Create an application that sends all medical images to the Pub/Sub topic.
Option2: B. Create a script that uses the gcloud storage command to synchronize the on-premises storage with Cloud Storage, Schedule the script as a cron job.
Option3: C. Create a Pub/Sub topic, and create a Cloud Function connected to the topic that writes data to Cloud Storage. Create an application that sends all medical images to the Pub/Sub topic.
Option4: D. In the Google Cloud console, go to Cloud Storage. Upload the relevant images to the appropriate bucket.

Content: Your company has an internal application for managing transactional orders. The application is used exclusively by employees in a single physical location. The application requires strong consistency, fast queries, and ACID guarantees for multi-table transactional updates. The first version of the application is implemented in PostgreSQL, and you want to deploy it to the cloud with minimal code changes. Which database is most appropriate for this application?
Option1: A. Bigtable
Option2: B. BigQuery
Option3: C. Cloud SQL
Option4: D. Firestore

Content: Your company runs one batch process in an on-premises server that takes around 30 hours to complete. The task runs monthly, can be performed offine, and must be restarted if interrupted. You want to migrate this workload to the cloud while minimizing cost. What should you do?
Option1: A. Create an Instance Template with Spot VMs On. Create a Managed Instance Group from the template and adjust Target CPU Utilization. Migrate the workload.
Option2: B. Migrate the workload to a Compute Engine VM. Start and stop the instance as needed.
Option3: C. Migrate the workload to a Google Kubernetes Engine cluster with Spot nodes.
Option4: D. Migrate the workload to a Compute Engine Spot VM.

Content: You are planning to migrate the following on-premises data management solutions to Google Cloud: ㆍOne MySQL cluster for your main database ㆍApache Kafka for your event streaming platform ㆍOne Cloud SQL for PostgreSQL database for your analytical and reporting needs You want to implement Google-recommended solutions for the migration. You need to ensure that the new solutions provide global scalability and require minimal operational and infrastructure management. What should you do?
Option1: A. Migrate from MySQL to Cloud SQL, from Kafka to Pub/Sub, and from Cloud SQL for PostgreSQL to BigQuery.
Option2: B. Migrate from MySQL to Cloud Spanner, from Kafka to Pub/Sub, and from Cloud SQL for PostgreSQL to BigQuery.
Option3: C. Migrate from MySQL to Cloud Spanner, from Kafka to Memorystore, and from Cloud SQL for PostgreSQL to Cloud SQL.
Option4: D. Migrate from MySQL to Cloud SQL, from Kafka to Memorystore, and from Cloud SQL for PostgreSQL to Cloud SQL.

Content: During a recent audit of your existing Google Cloud resources, you discovered several users with email addresses outside of your Google Workspace domain. You want to ensure that your resources are only shared with users whose email addresses match your domain. You need to remove any mismatched users, and you want to avoid having to audit your resources to identify mismatched users. What should you do?
Option1: A. Create a Cloud Scheduler task to regularly scan your projects and delete mismatched users.
Option2: B. Create a Cloud Scheduler task to regularly scan your resources and delete mismatched users.
Option3: C. Set an organizational policy constraint to limit identities by domain to automatically remove mismatched users.
Option4: D. Set an organizational policy constraint to limit identities by domain, and then retroactively remove the existing mismatched users

Content: Your application is running on Google Cloud in a managed instance group (MIG). You see errors in Cloud Logging for one VM that one of the processes is not responsive. You want to replace this VM in the MIG quickly. What should you do?
Option1: A. Use the gcloud compute instances update command with a REFRESH action for the VM.
Option2: B. Use the gcloud compute instance-groups managed recreate-instances command to recreate the VM.
Option3: C. Select the MIG from the Compute Engine console and, in the menu, select Replace VMs.
Option4: D. Update and apply the instance template of the MIG.

Content: You want to permanently delete a Pub/Sub topic managed by Config Connector in your Google Cloud project. What should you do?
Option1: A. Use kubectl to create the label deleted-by-cnrm and to change its value to true for the topic resource.
Option2: B. Use kubectl to delete the topic resource.
Option3: C. Use cloud CLI to delete the topic.
Option4: D. Use gcloud CLI to update the topic label managed-by-crm to false.

Content: Your company is using Google Workspace to manage employee accounts. Anticipated growth will increase the number of personnel from 100 employees to 1,000 employees within 2 years. Most employees will need access to your company's Google Cloud account. The systems and processes will need to support 10x growth without performance degradation, unnecessary complexity, or security issues. What should you do?
Option1: A. Migrate the users to Active Directory. Connect the Human Resources system to Active Directory. Turn on Google Cloud Directory Sync (GCDS) for Cloud Identity. Turn on Identity Federation from Cloud Identity to Active Directory.
Option2: B. Organize the users in Cloud Identity into groups. Enforce multi-factor authentication in Cloud Identity.
Option3: C. Turn on identity federation between Cloud Identity and Google Workspace. Enforce multi-factor authentication for domain wide delegation.
Option4: D. Use a third-party identity provider service through federation. Synchronize the users from Google Workplace to the third-party provider in real time.

Content: You want to host your video encoding software on Compute Engine. Your user base is growing rapidly, and users need to be able to encode their videos at any time without interruption or CPU limitations. You must ensure that your encoding solution is highly available, and you want to follow Google-recommended practices to automate operations. What should you do?
Option1: A. Deploy your solution on multiple standalone Compute Engine instances, and increase the number of existing instances when CPU utilization on Cloud Monitoring reaches a certain threshold.
Option2: B. Deploy your solution on multiple standalone Compute Engine instances, and replace existing instances with high-CPU instances when CPU utilization on Cloud Monitoring reaches a certain threshold.
Option3: C. Deploy your solution to an instance group, and increase the number of available instances whenever you see high CPU utilization in Cloud Monitoring.
Option4: D. Deploy your solution to an instance group, and set the autoscaling based on CPU utilization.

Content: Your managed instance group raised an alert stating that new instance creation has failed to create new instances. You need to solve the instance creation problem. What should you do?
Option1: A. Create an instance template that contains valid syntax which will be used by the instance group. Delete any persistent disks with the same name as instance names.
Option2: B. Create an instance template that contains valid syntax that will be used by the instance group. Verify that the instance name and persistent disk name values are not the same in the template.
Option3: C. Verify that the instance template being used by the instance group contains valid syntax. Delete any persistent disks with the same name as instance names. Set the disks autoDelete property to true in the instance template.
Option4: D. Delete the current instance template and replace it with a new instance template. Verify that the instance name and persistent disk name values are not the same in the template. Set the disks.autoDelete property to true in the instance template.

Content: You have created an application that is packaged into a Docker image. You want to deploy the Docker image as a workload on Google Kubernetes Engine. What should you do?
Option1: A. Upload the image to Cloud Storage and create a Kubernetes Service referencing the image.
Option2: B. Upload the image to Cloud Storage and create a Kubernetes Deployment referencing the image.
Option3: C. Upload the image to Artifact Registry and create a Kubernetes Service referencing the image.
Option4: D. Upload the image to Artifact Registry and create a Kubernetes Deployment referencing the image.

Content: You are using Looker Studio to visualize a table from your data warehouse that is built on top of BigQuery. Data is appended to the data warehouse during the day. At night, the daily summary is recalculated by overwriting the table. You just noticed that the charts in Looker Studio are broken, and you want to analyze the problem. What should you do?
Option1: A. In Cloud Logging, create a filter for your Looker Studio report.
Option2: B. Use the open source CLI tool, Snapshot Debugger, to find out why the data was not refreshed correctly.
Option3: C. Review the Error Reporting page in the Google Cloud console to find any errors.
Option4: D. Use the BigQuery interface to review the nightly job and look for any errors.

Content: You have a batch workload that runs every night and uses a large number of virtual machines (VMs). It is fault-tolerant and can tolerate some of the VMs being terminated. The current cost of VMs is too high. What should you do?
Option1: A. Run a test using simulated maintenance events. If the test is successful, use Spot N2 Standard VMs when running future jobs.
Option2: B. Run a test using simulated maintenance events. If the test is successful, use N2 Standard VMs when running future jobs.
Option3: C. Run a test using a managed instance group. If the test is successful, use N2 Standard VMs in the managed instance group when running future jobs.
Option4: D. Run a test using N1 standard VMs instead of N2. If the test is successful, use N1 Standard VMs when running future jobs.

Content: You created several resources in multiple Google Cloud projects. All projects are linked to different billing accounts. To better estimate future charges, you want to have a single visual representation of all costs incurred. You want to include new cost data as soon as possible. What should you do?
Option1: A. Fill all resources in the Pricing Calculator to get an estimate of the monthly cost.
Option2: B. Use the Reports view in the Cloud Billing Console to view the desired cost information.
Option3: C. Visit the Cost Table page to get a CSV export and visualize it using Looker Studio.
Option4: D. Configure Billing Data Export to BigQuery and visualize the data in Looker Studio.

Content: Your company has a large quantity of unstructured data in different file formats. You want to perform ETL transformations on the data. You need to make the data accessible on Google Cloud so it can be processed by a Dataflow job. What should you do?
Option1: A. Upload the data to BigQuery using the bq command line tool.
Option2: B. Upload the data to Cloud Storage using the glcoud storage command.
Option3: C. Upload the data into Cloud SQL using the import function in the Google Cloud console.
Option4: D. Upload the data into Cloud Spanner using the import function in the Google Cloud console.

Content: You have deployed an application on a single Compute Engine instance. The application writes logs to disk. Users start reporting errors with the application. You want to diagnose the problem. What should you do?
Option1: A. Navigate to Cloud Logging and view the application logs.
Option2: B. Connect to the instance's serial console and read the application logs.
Option3: C. Configure a health check on the instance and set a "consecutive successes" threshold value of 1.
Option4: D. Install and configure the Ops agent and view the logs from Cloud Logging.

Content: You recently received a new Google Cloud project with an attached billing account where you will work. You need to create instances, set firewalls, and store data in Cloud Storage. You want to follow Google-recommended practices. What should you do?
Option1: A. Use the gcloud CLI services enable cloudresourcemanager.googleapis.com command to enable all resources.
Option2: B. Use the gcloud services enable compute.googleapis.com command to enable Compute Engine and the gcloud services enable storage-api.googleapis.com command to enable the Cloud Storage APIs.
Option3: C. Open the Google Cloud console and enable all Google Cloud APIs from the API dashboard.
Option4: D. Open the Google Cloud console and run gcloud init --project in a Cloud Shell.

Content: Your team is developing a Cloud Function triggered by Cloud Storage events. You want to accelerate testing and development of your Cloud Function while following Google-recommended best practices. What should you do?
Option1: A. Create a new Cloud Function that is triggered when Cloud Audit Logs detects the cloudfunctions.functions.sourceCodeSet operation in the original Cloud Function. Send mock requests to the new function to evaluate the functionality.
Option2: B. Make a copy of the Cloud Function, and rewrite the code to be HTTP-triggered. Edit and test the new version by triggering the HTTP endpoint. Send mock requests to the new function to evaluate the functionality.
Option3: C. Install the Functions Frameworks library, and configure the Cloud Function on localhost. Make a copy of the function, and make edits to the new version. Test the new version using curl.
Option4: D. Make a copy of the Cloud Function in the Google Cloud console. Use the Cloud console's in-line editor to make source code changes to the new function. Modify your web application to call the new function, and test the new version in production

Content: Your team is setting up a build pipeline for an application that will run in Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE). For security reasons, you only want images produced by the pipeline to be deployed to your GKE cluster. Which combination of Google Cloud services should you use?
Option1: A. Cloud Build, Cloud Storage, and Binary Authorization
Option2: B. Google Cloud Deploy, Cloud Storage, and Google Cloud Armor
Option3: C. Google Cloud Deploy, Artifact Registry, and Google Cloud Armor
Option4: D. Cloud Build, Artifact Registry, and Binary Authorization

Content: You are supporting a business-critical application in production deployed on Cloud Run. The application is reporting HTTP 500 errors that are affecting the usability of the application. You want to be alerted when the number of errors exceeds 15% of the requests within a specific time window. What should you do?
Option1: A. Create a Cloud Function that consumes the Cloud Monitoring API. Use Cloud Scheduler to trigger the Cloud Function daily and alert you if the number of errors is above the defined threshold.
Option2: B. Navigate to the Cloud Run page in the Google Cloud console, and select the service from the services list. Use the Metrics tab to visualize the number of errors for that revision, and refresh the page daily.
Option3: C. Create an alerting policy in Cloud Monitoring that alerts you if the number of errors is above the defined threshold.
Option4: D. Create a Cloud Function that consumes the Cloud Monitoring API. Use Cloud Composer to trigger the Cloud Function daily and alert you if the number of errors is above the defined threshold.

Content: You need to build a public API that authenticates, enforces quotas, and reports metrics for API callers. Which tool should you use to complete this architecture?
Option1: A. App Engine
Option2: B. Cloud Endpoints
Option3: C. Identity-Aware Proxy
Option4: D. GKE Ingress for HTTP(S) Load Balancing

Content: You are running multiple microservices in a Kubernetes Engine cluster. One microservice is rendering images. The microservice responsible for the image rendering requires a large amount of CPU time compared to the memory it requires. The other microservices are workloads that are optimized for n2 standard machine types. You need to optimize your cluster so that all workloads are using resources as efficiently as possible. What should you do?
Option1: A. Assign the pods of the image rendering microservice a higher pod priority than the other microservices.
Option2: B. Create a node pool with compute-optimized machine type nodes for the image rendering microservice, Use the node pool with general-purpose machine type nodes for the other microservices.
Option3: C. Use the node pool with general-purpose machine type nodes for the image rendering microservice. Create a node pool with compute-optimized machine type nodes for the other microservices.
Option4: D. Configure the required amount of CPU and memory in the resource requests specification of the image rendering microservice deployment. Keep the resource requests for the other microservices at the default.

Content: You are working in a team that has developed a new application that needs to be deployed on Kubernetes. The production application is business-critical and should be optimized for reliability. You need to provision a Kubernetes cluster and want to follow Google recommended practices. What should you do?
Option1: A. Create a GKE Autopilot cluster. Enroll the cluster in the rapid release channel
Option2: B. Create a GKE Autopilot cluster. Enroll the cluster in the stable release channel
Option3: C. Create a zonal GKE standard cluster. Enroll the cluster in the stable release channel.
Option4: D. Create a regional GKE standard cluster. Enroll the cluster in the rapid release channel.

Content: You are responsible for a web application on Compute Engine. You want your support team to be notified automatically if users experience high latency for at least 5 minutes. You need a Google-recommended solution with no development cost. What should you do?
Option1: A. Export Cloud Monitoring metrics to BigQuery and use a Looker Studio dashboard to monitor your web application's latency.
Option2: B. Create an alert policy to send a notification when the HTTP response latency exceeds the specified threshold.
Option3: C. Implement an App Engine service that invokes the Cloud Monitoring API and sends a notification in case of anomalies.
Option4: D. Use the Cloud Monitoring dashboard to observe latency and take the necessary actions when the response latency exceeds the specified threshold

Content: You have an on-premises data analytics set of binaries that processes data files in memory for about 45 minutes every midnight. The sizes of those data files range from 1 gigabyte to 16 gigabytes. You want to migrate this application to Google Cloud with minimal effort and cost. What should you do?
Option1: A. Create a container for the set of binaries. Use Cloud Scheduler to start a Cloud Run job for the container.
Option2: B. Create a container for the set of binaries. Deploy the container to Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE) and use the Kubernetes scheduler to start the application.
Option3: C. Upload the code to Cloud Functions. Use Cloud Scheduler to start the application.
Option4: D. Lift and shift to a VM on Compute Engine. Use an instance schedule to start and stop the instance.

Content: You used the gcloud container clusters command to create two Google Cloud Kubernetes (GKE) clusters: prod-cluster and dev-cluster. * prod-cluster is a standard cluster. ㆍ dev-cluster is an auto-pilot cluster. When you run the kubectI get nodes command, you only see the nodes from prod-cluster. Which commands should you run to check the node status for dev-cluster?
Option1: A. 'gcloud container clusters get-credentials dev-cluster' 'kubectl get nodes'
Option2: B. 'gcloud container clusters update -generate-password dev-cluster' 'kubecti get nodes'
Option3: C. 'kubectI config set-context dev-cluster' 'kubectl cluster-info'
Option4: D. 'kubectl config set-credentials dev-cluster' 'kubectl cluster-info'

Content: You recently discovered that your developers are using many service account keys during their development process. While you work on a long term improvement, you need to quickly implement a process to enforce short-lived service account credentials in your company. You have the following requirements: ㆍ All service accounts that require a key should be created in a centralized project called pj-sa. ㆍService account keys should only be valid for one day. You need a Google-recommended solution that minimizes cost. What should you do?
Option1: A. Implement a Cloud Run job to rotate all service account keys periodically in pj-sa. Enforce an org policy to deny service account key creation with an exception to pj-sa.
Option2: B. Implement a Kubernetes CronJob to rotate all service account keys periodically. Disable attachment of service accounts to resources in all projects with an exception to pj-sa.
Option3: C. Enforce an org policy constraint allowing the lifetime of service account keys to be 24 hours. Enforce an org policy constraint denying service account key creation with an exception on pi-sa.
Option4: D. Enforce a DENY org policy constraint over the lifetime of service account keys for 24 hours. Disable attachment of service accounts to resources in all projectswith an exception to pj-sa.

Content: Your company is running a three-tier web application on virtual machines that use a MySQL database. You need to create an estimated total cost of cloud infrastructure to run this application on Google Cloud instances and Cloud SQL. What should you do?
Option1: A. Create a Google spreadsheet with multiple Google Cloud resource combinations. On a separate sheet, import the current Google Cloud prices and use these prices for the calculations within formulas.
Option2: B. Use the Google Cloud Pricing Calculator and select the Cloud Operations template to define your web application with as much detail as possible.
Option3: C. Implement a similar architecture on Google Cloud, and run a reasonable load test on a smaller scale. Check the billing information, and calculate the estimated costs based on the real load your system usually handles.
Option4: D. Use the Google Cloud Pricing Calculator to determine the cost of every Google Cloud resource you expect to use. Use similar size instances for the web server, and use your current on-premises machines as a comparison for Cloud SQL.

Content: You have a Bigtable instance that consists of three nodes that store personally identifiable information (PI) data. You need to log all read or write operations, including any metadata or configuration reads of this database table, in your company's Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) system. What should you do?
Option1: A. • Navigate to Cloud Monitoring in the Google Cloud console, and create a custom monitoring job for the Bigtable instance to track all changes. • Create an alert by using webhook endpoints, with the SIEM endpoint as a receiver.
Option2: B. • Navigate to the Audit Logs page in the Google Cloud console, and enable Admin Write logs for the Bigtable instance. • Create a Cloud Functions instance to export logs from Cloud Logging to your SIEM.
Option3: C. • Navigate to the Audit Logs page in the Google Cloud console, and enable Data Read, Data Write and Admin Read logs for the Bigtable instance. • Create a Pub/Sub topic as a Cloud Logging sink destination, and add your SIEM as a subscriber to the topic.
Option4: D. • Install the Ops Agent on the Bigtable instance during configuration. • Create a service account with read permissions for the Bigtable instance. • Create a custom Dataflow job with this service account to export logs to the company's SIM system.

Content: You want to set up a Google Kubernetes Engine cluster. Verifiable node identity and integrity are required for the cluster, and nodes cannot be accessed from the internet. You want to reduce the operational cost of managing your cluster, and you want to follow Google-recommended practices. What should you do?
Option1: A. Deploy a private autopilot cluster.
Option2: B. Deploy a public autopilot cluster.
Option3: C. Deploy a standard public cluster and enable shielded nodes.
Option4: D. Deploy a standard private cluster and enable shielded nodes.

Content: Your company wants to migrate their on-premises workloads to Google Cloud. The current on-premises workloads consist of • A Flask web application • A backend API • A scheduled long-running background job for ETL and reporting You need to keep operational costs low. You want to follow Google-recommended practices to migrate these workloads to serverless solutions on Google Cloud. What should you do?
Option1: A. Migrate the web application to App Engine and the backend API to Cloud Run. Use Cloud Tasks to run your background job on Compute Engine.
Option2: B. Migrate the web application to App Engine and the backend API to Cloud Run. Use Cloud Tasks to run your background job on Cloud Run.
Option3: C. Run the web application on a Cloud Storage bucket and the backend API on Cloud Run. Use Cloud Tasks to run your background job on Cloud Run.
Option4: D. Run the web application on a Cloud Storage bucket and the backend API on Cloud Run. Use Cloud Tasks to run your background job on Compute Engine.
